content:
When you say 'Remove' - what is the intention ?

Do you want to delete them ? Do you want to sort them into other folders so it's easier to organise etc.

It's somewhat risky to have a lot of emails in one folder. At this point, it's not known if there is any type of corruption in that Inbox especially if you have tons of emails and the file size may be even larger if you have deleted or moved any emails and not been compacting. So when proceeding let's assume there maybe corruption which could impact on results later on. I would not like to only have good emails in an Inbox which I will need to compact and do not know if that file has an unknown problem, hence adise to move good first.

At this point do not compact anything this is vitally important. I'm going to advise you to do this in a way that will not lose emails if there is any unknown issue with that Inbox. It may seem odd but it's all because you have an old Inbox brimming with emails and the file state is unknown. I'm assuming you have more unwanted emails than good wanted emails. So it's alot quicker to move what you want than what you do not want.

Are you using a Pop or IMAP account ? If IMAP then anything you delete - it will get deleted off the server. I would also advise if this is an imap account then use 'Copy to' to another folder because if something goes wrong with a 'Move to' you may lose email.

First: Create a new folder with a suitable name or create better still several new folders and then you can move emails into suitable folder eg: Family, Friends, Online Orders, Hobby, etc

Second: I would advise you move all the good wanted emails out of the Inbox and put them in the new folder(s) you created.

How to move a batch of emails: If they are listed one after the other - click on first email, hold down shift key and click on last. All emails in between become highlighted/selected. Right click on highlighted emails and select 'Move to' and choose the relevant new folder you created.

If they are in various locations throughout: you could sort by 'From' and then move batches of same email address into same folder. OR Hold down 'Ctrl' key whilst clicking on various emails to select. Right click on highlighted emails and select 'Move to' and choose the relevant new folder you created. All the highlighted emails move as one batch to designated folder.

When all the good emails have been moved out of the Inbox, this will leave all the emails you want to delete in the Inbox.

Third: Now to kill/delete all the unwanted emails left in Inbox.

  • Select top email in Inbox
  • Hold down 'Ctrl' key and press 'A' key

This will highlight all the unwanted emails in the Inbox

  • The Message Pane will say X conversations and offer two buttons 'Archive' and 'Delete'.
  • Click on 'Delete'

Last: When Inbox is empty, you need to clean up all old traces of moved and deleted emails. This is important.

  • Right click on 'Inbox' and select 'Compact'

This will leave you with a clean new empty Inbox ready for use.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
You have subscribed to see the gmail 'All Mail' folder which is a complete duplication of everything. It does not really offer anything that's useful. If anything should happen to that file and it synchronised with server , you could lose everything.

Suggestion: - Unsubscribe from seeing the 'All Mail' folder so you can rule it out.

Now Exit Thunderbird This should get all the background files updated. Access profile and delete the global-messages-db.sqlite file

Restart Thunderbird.

Please report back on results

content:
I think I think the indexing is fixed by repeatedly repairing and indexing.

This is what I think I learned. Does it look right?

Searching is supported by an internal SQLite database which is stored in the profile folder as global-messages-db.sqlite. This can be deleted (after quitting Thunderbird) and it will be automatically be rebuilt when Thunderbird restarts.

You can view the rebuild process in Activity Manager - Tools | Activity Manager

Errors are displayed in the Error Console - Tools | Developer Tools | Error console

The indexing (rebuilding) of the database can stop if one of the folders (msf files) is corrupted. The folder and account that stopped indexing will be shown in Activity Manager log. Right click on that folder, then Properties, then Repair will redownload all messages from the account and rebuild the corrupted folder. Then restarting Thunderbird should resume indexing (you don't have to delete the database and start again from scratch).
creator: camerojo

content:
camerojo said
I have one folder left that the indexing stops on. That folder is associated with an old account that no longer exists. Is there any way that I can repair that folder so that it can be indexed for searching purposes?

Is that folder in 'Local Folders' account ? Or is that folder still in an old POP account which you still have displaying in Folder Pane? OR is that folder still in an old IMAP account which you still have displaying? I would not have expected it to be this last option because it's normal to get fully downloaded copies of wanted mail put into Local Folders before deleting all email from the account to clear data off server. Then you would remove the imap account and then remove account from server/supplier of email address. However, looking at error console data, it's implying it cannot access server which is usually associated with imap account. Suggestion - if that folder is in an imap account, then create a folder in Local Folders and get copies of all emails put into that folder. Check you have good copies before removing the redundant imap account.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: camerojo

content:
re :I can create a new local folder but I don't know how to copy the emails I have in the old inactive imap account to the new local folder.

In Local Folders' account create a new folder - for the sake of this example I'll call it 'Old Account', but if required you can create more than one folder so you can organise emails.

In old imap account folder:

  • Right click on highlighted email and select 'Copy to' and choose Local Folders > 'Old Account'

You can get copies of batches of emails - let's say 10

  • Click on first email - Hold Down 'Shift' key and click on approx 10th email - all emails in between get highlighted.
  • Right click on highlighted emails and select 'Copy to' and choose Local Folders > 'Old Account'

Advise you randomly select a few of those copied emails to check you can read them - it means they were copied over correctly. Repeat process to get copies into 'Old Account' folder.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: It is not Thunderbird, but thunderbird is sending from your IP address, whereas when you send from website, you're using their IP address. Thunderbird has nothing in it to make decisions on whether to send a message or not. When you click the 'send' button, thunderbird launches the message into the internet and then reports whatever message is returned. The error message continues to show you who is sending the error - bluewin. it's right there in the message, so I am puzzled why you keep believing otherwise.

content:
Did you know freezing is not crashing and using the incorrect term is a sure sign you will have difficulty finding answers. When something is not responding and you try and search using the word crash nothing that is returned is relevant. When you post in this forum and say crash, you are asked for crash id references that you can not offer because you are not crashing. You are hanging or not responding.

Thunderbird is not responding, now as you have deleted a lot of mail, it might be it is still processing that. Or it could be your antivirus is messing up Thunderbird because it is trying to make major changes to files stored on the hard disk. Do you have an exception in your antivirus for the Thunderbird profile folder?

creator: sbarziza1

content:
Anti-Virus would need to be set up to not scan anything in the Thunderbird profile folders. Otherwise they can any file that gets opened.

It depends upon where you got the Thunderbird installation, but if you got Thunderbird from this location:

  • https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

Then this is the location of the 'Thunderbird' folder you need to set up as exempt from scanning and then it should not scan anything it contains. C://Users/username/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird


After you deleted a load of emails from say 'Inbox', I would recommend you compact the 'Inbox' to remove all old traces of deleted or moved emails.

  • Right click on Inbox and select 'compact'

It's basic housekeeping and required maintenance, reduces files size and helps to reduce the risks of corruption. Recommend you do not use the folder whilst this is in operation, it usually only lasts a few seconds and do not exit Thunderbird if compacting is in progress.

Typically, Inbox, Drafts, Junk/Spam are the folders that get the most action when it comes to deleting or moving mail, so a regular manual compact on those folders should help alot.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: I want thank everyone that replied to my problem and offered very good advice. I want to follow up with my problem that I had, which was Thunderbird would freeze up after I attempted to try and delete 1 GB worth of emails. Ya 1 GB worth, I had no idea. One thing that I did was leave Thunderbird alone. I went into Outlook and setup my 4 email accounts. Once I did that I started to delete old emails, a few hundred at a time. I deleted quit a bit. Next thing I did after deleting emails in Outlook, I went into Thunderbird and right clicked on the one email account that was causing problems or would not open at all. I then selected properties, then I selected repair folder. Then I went into retention policy and selected do not delete emails or save all emails. Before I had it set to delete emails over 30 days old. I believe that may have caused my problems. So after all of that, I have my Thunderbird back. No problems. So if you have to delete emails, a lot, I would take my time, see how much you have in emails [1GB or more] how much RAM do you have on your computer. I would also advise to not let your emails pile up. Thanks a lot Sam

content:
I presume these accounts are on the same version of thunderbird. My first suggestion is this - click to her email account pane - on bottom line is 'Outgoing Server; - click the button 'edit outgoing server' - does this pane show her email address or yours? If it shows yours, then her setting is not being used. DO NOT change this, as her account may be pointing to yours, and changing might reverse the problem. instead,

- click to account settings pane - at bottom of left side bar is link to outgoing servers pane. click it - there, you should see an SMTP server setting for her account. Edit the DESCRIPTION field to have her name - then, return to her account pane and on the bottom line, click the drop-down menu and select the SMTP server that you just renamed.
creator: davidsk

content:
It's funny, I have the very same problem in my Thunderbird 143 profile and can't find the culprit. So I created a new profile with TB 140.3.1esr and the problem is solved. This issue can happen if in Account Settings > account name > Copies & Folders > Drafts & Templates you designate your Inbox as the destination folder for Drafts messages. So I would verify this setting in the first place.

If you don't find the culprit you can install the add-on "FolderFlags" https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-us/thunderbird/addon/folderflags/ which will allow you to edit the flags Thunderbird sets on folders. This add-on works with TB versions up to 142*, so you could give it a try. It adds a "Flags" category in the Folder Properties window (image)

content:
it is exceedingly difficult to find a setting that does not exist.

There is no successful method of "Pausing and account" if you account is IMAP. Usually if the account is not available on the server at some point all the mail held in Thunderbird will be deleted. A pop account you just disable the checking of mail in account settings, but that does not work effectively for IMAP account and that is what almost everyone has.

The idea has already been submitted to the ideas forum https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/ability-to-deactivate-email-accounts-in-thunderbird-temporarily/idi-p/81979 and https://connect.mozilla.org/t5/ideas/allow-thunderbird-user-to-enable-disable-an-account-temporarily/idi-p/29194

This is not the place to discuss a wishlist.

content:
re :I have installed, uninstalled, and reinstalled Thunderbird four times -

Let's be clear, there are very few instances when anyone would need to uninstall and reinstall Thunderbird. The reason being usually issues have nothing to do with the program itself.

re :I can NOT get any of the folders from Outlook to show up

Check you have the following setting:

  • 'View' > 'Folders' > 'All' - ( disable/de-select any others that may be selected)

Confirm you have that setting.

Q: Do you see the account name in the Folder Pane ? Post an image showing the Folder Pane so we can see what you see.


Q: Do you mean you have an imap mail account set up to access the office365 server? If yes, then post the following information so we can check you are using correct settings.

  • 'Account Settings' > 'Server Settings' for the outlook account.
  • post image which shows all the top section - Server Type, server name, port, connection security, authentication method.

Q: Are you talking about a microsoft email addess - does it end with @hotmail.com or @live.com or @outlook.com ?

In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll down to 'Mail and News Accounts' section
  • Copy all data and paste it into this forum question.

If Imap account - check the subscribing.

  • Right click on the outlook account name in Folder Pane (assuming it exists)
  • select 'Subscribe'
  • Click on 'Refresh'
  • Select all folders, so they have the checkbox and are highlighted
  • click on 'Subscribe'
  • Click on 'OK'

Q: What did you see in the subscribe list ?

Q: Are you getting any errors that say cannot access server or requesting password etc ? If yes, please post an image of that error pop up message.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:

Q: Have you considered setting it up on server via webmail to auto forward emails from outlook to gmail account ?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
I notice you mention POP and you also mention Gmail. It's common to have Thunderbiord pop account using these setting 'Leave messages on server' It's also common to choose one the options for deleting such as 'Until I delete them'

Unfortuantely, it's not possible for Pop accounts to put deleted emails into the gmail Trash, so when you delete, gmail just removes the Inbox label and keeps emails archived in 'All Mail'.

It is a known coincidence that Gmail deliberately stops allowing the download when it detects users are using Pop on a third party email client like Thunderbird. It seems they are causing an annoyance because they want you to access the webmail account and sort out/delete emails.

So - just in case this particular issue is effecting the gmail account do the following to rule it out because we dod not know whether there is more than one issue going on.

In all of those cases I've been involved with and there have been quite a few - the following has always fixed the issue.

  • Logon to Gmail webmail account via a browser.
  • Access 'All Mail' folder

If you choose to delete an email from 'All Mail' they will be removed from Inbox etc so it saves time doing it in that folder. Delete a load of old emails and any emails that have no label to seriously reduce the contents of the 'All Mail' folder. Then empty the gmail Trash. Note Gmail will auto clear emails from Spam and Trash periodically - usually they remove anything thats been in those folders every 30 days.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
This is the simplest way to transfer from win10 to win 11:

Here is the link for moving a profile in Windows when installed in default location: 

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/moving-thunderbird-data-to-a-new-computer

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This may prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it
  8. start thunderbird and all should be there

That approach copies 100% of the profile: contacts, accounts, all email, settings. Since you have copied some elements, to help you, I suggest advising whether your account is POP or IMAP, and please be explicit on which components did not transfer. You're right, in that the elements are in the old profile can can be copied individually from one profile to another. We can advise steps for that. However, if your account is IMAP, it may be simpler to just do the steps as defined above. Let me know.
creator: davidsk

content:
New mail indication will only be displayed on folder and on emails providing the following occurs.

The folder has not been selected since the new mail arrived in it. Example: It you select a folder to see new mail, but do not open anything because you decide to come back to it later and then select another folder. You will notice the original folder that did have the new mail no longer shows as blue and when you reselect it all the new mail will now just be unread - not new unread. That's because there have been no new mail since you last viewed folder.

So whether 'new' mail displays or not depends upon whether you have previously selected a folder that contained new mail.

re: Filtering: is this you performing a manual filter on folder or is this the auto filtering upon download to Inbox? Are you talking about a Pop or Imap mail account? Are you filtering from eg: Imap Inbox to Imap same account folder OR from Imap Inbox to Local Folders account folder ?

What server eg: gmail, outlook, AT&T, BT etc?
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
so from what I understand you are implicitly deleting the mail from one account and then adding it to another, both being IMAP accounts you can not actually move from one to another.

Is the filter set to execute after junk processing. this occurs after a complete local download of the message body, Usually filters work when the meta data excluding the message body is received adding the delay for spam processing allows for time to get all the data you are going to be moving instead of some of it.
creator: MattAuSupport

It works, sometimes, hence post here. 2) Following your suggestion, I did just chg the filter to act "after" junk mail weedout. We'll see how that works. Thank you.
creator: linusr

content:
linusr said
Hi Matt, read your reply, thanks. 1) I don't see the process as a deletion

Email is in WallysWorld@Somewhere.com you "move" it to Franko@wallyworld.com If the account is IMAP that means the mail is deleted from WallysWorld@Somewhere.com. IMAP has no way to move an email from one account to another.

Certainly if the account is POP there is only local copies of mail involved and they can be moved. But as you have not said what mail protocol you use I have assumed the default (IMAP)

What you have just said is you copy the mail and make a new copy retaining the old. This iat odds with your initial post were you said.

linusr said
sometimes I have to physically delete the msg.

That does not sound like making a new copy and retaining the old in the account it came into.

SO we can be sure I am not lost and we are on the same page. Please check the account settings for the account the messages are coming for and the account they are going to and confirm if they are IMAP or POP

Unless you have issues with your antivirus program, quite likely they are poor products when put under a microscope for efficiency and stability. You almost certainly have an IMAP account in there as they are the ones most likely to demonstrate unstable filtering unless it is done after junk processing. Please prove me wrong and determine if you need an exception in your antivirus product for the Thunderbird profile folder to allow Thunderbird to actually work without the incessant and lengthy delays scanning causes. Updates from filters can't be saved because the scanning is taking longer per folder than the time between accesses.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Calendar data is in the profile folder/calendar-data folder

To open your TB profile:

- TB menu > Help > Troubleshooting Information

- click the Application Basics > Profile Folder 'Open Folder' button

Address books are also in the profile folder - they begin with abook. May be best to export them by R. clicking an address book > Export.

It really wouldn't hurt to back up the whole profile folder if you have the space somewhere.
